all_paragraphs: At the beginning of my AI learning journey, I wished I had some mentors that could guide me in the right direction.
I needed guidance in my approach of studying machine learning especially when the first book I purchased to learn ML was a rather formidable foe.
Two years and a lot of model.fit() later, I’m now a professional ML/Computer Vision Engineer.

Individuals starting of their journey in AI or just looking for advice reach out to me and ask questions via LinkedIn. Having an understanding of how hard it can be when trying to navigate the world of AI, I always try my best to answer all the questions that are posted to me via LinkedIn or email.
Perhaps there are some questions you’ve meant to ask. Have a look at the questions below, and maybe you might find some guidance.
If none of the answers I provide is useful to you, then scroll down to the conclusion section and find out how to ask me your question directly.
On that note, let’s dive in.

Would you recommend a masters in Data Science (as offered by most Universities) or a masters in some specialised field? Kindly do advise from the point of view of job opportunities in the respective domains as well.
I would recommend getting an MSc in Data Science if you are confident that you are only interested in employment opportunities within Data Science roles.
There still seems to be a high demand for Data Scientists despite the current pandemic and the difficulties some industries are experiencing.
At the same time, there is also an increased supply of data scientists, which translates to more competitions for roles.
Exceptional Data Scientists that are at the top of their game find roles very quickly.
However, you might want to pursue a masters in a more specialised field if you know where your interests and passion lies.
If you are interested in areas such as Computer Vision, Natural Language Processing or Robotics, then taking a more specialised MSc seems like a logical choice.
And since they are more technical and specialised, there might not be as much competition for job roles, when compared comparison for roles in Data Science.

Another critical point is that some of the skills you gain from specialised degrees in Computer Vision or NLP are transferable to generic Data Science roles. So, you can have a masters in a technical field such as computer vision and still have the relevant skills of a data scientist.
Take me, for example, even though I studied a masters in machine learning and computer vision, I still had the skills necessary to apply for Data Science jobs.
My first couple of interviews before I got my job as a Computer vision engineer were for Data Science roles.
What are relevant courses and insights for learning autonomous field?
My experience and knowledge within the field autonomous field is very minimal.
Nonetheless, I will provide some useful information I found through online research on the internet and intuition.

The autonomous field will coincide with autonomous vehicle and robotics. The dominant area of autonomous vehicles will be in regards to sensors and vision-based methods autonomous vehicles use to gain perception and understanding of the environment.
Other areas that a prevalent within autonomous vehicle study is navigation systems and map planning.

As a starting point, take a look at this course and see if it meets your learning requirements.
Autonomous robots and vehicle have a place in the technological future of humanity.
Look at amazon warehouses that are packed with autonomous robots. Several delivery systems will be adopting self-navigating robots within the next 5–10 years.
Tesla just recently released a beta version of their full self-driving system and are even planning on expanding it to more cities.
I live in the United Kingdom, and I’ve seen some companies testing delivery robots in busy urban areas.
Could you inform me of the requirements needed to apply for a job as a Deep Learning / Computer Vision Engineer?
Most ML/CV Engineering roles require individuals that are strong in at least two programming languages, and Python is an industry favourite.
Also, experience using cloud computing services providers such as GCP, AWS, Azure are sought after, but they tend to be a desirable requirement.
Having experience using machine learning libraries such as PyTorch, TensorFlow, or Keras is a standard requirement that most, if not all, job roles advertise for ML Engineers include.

How well does AI currently analyse video, and what does the future look like for AI video analysis?
To directly answer your question, Deep Learning techniques can generally analyse video very well.
Deep learning techniques are good enough to be able to describe the contents and context of videos.
For example, AI is very good at tracking multiple individuals within consecutive video frames and also perform facial recognition on videos that humans might not even be able to.
Deep learning solutions to pose estimation are capable of detecting the location of human joints, in realtime from video data.

The future for AI video analysis is very bright. In the future, we will probably witness video analysis utilised in most form of live entertainment such as football matches, streamed concerts and many more.
To me, it seems like the logical step forward.
To paint a scenario, currently, when we watch football or any sports, we listen to human commentators. I believe within the next decade or two, we will observe the emergence of AI commentators.
Take a look at this video summarising research work that analyses videos of tennis played by real humans and then generates impressive gameplay of a tennis match.
How essential is linear algebra and calculus needed in the field of computer vision and AI? What topics should I cover within these subfields of mathematics as a beginner?
From an academic perspective, understanding linear algebra is paramount to having a strong knowledge of specific topics within computer vision and deep learning.
Before the advent of deep learning and convolutional neural networks, a lot of computer vision techniques utilised a lot of heuristic intuitions and algorithms that were heavily reliant on maths.
A simple example will be a typical transformation or augmentation algorithm that uses mathematical functions to transform image data from one state to another.
If we move to more advanced topics within computer vision such as deep learning, then understanding calculus is essential to understand some foundational concept on how neural networks learn.
The topic of backpropagation and optimisation algorithms is heavily maths based.
From an academic standpoint, understanding all mathematical areas that are associated with machine learning will provide you with an advantage in your studies.
Do you make use of a lot of pre-trained models/libraries, etc.?
In a professional environment, you tend to utilise a lot of pretrained models.
Simply kept, you will rarely develop algorithms or neural networks from scratch (except you work within ML research).
Transfer Learning and Fine-tuning are considerable aspects of applied AI and practical machine learning.
There is more emphasis on software engineering and ML model integration when looking at practical AI.

In terms of libraries, TensorFlow is used in practical use cases, especially with the TFlite library. TensorFlow Lite focuses on ML provisioning on edge devices. PyTorch and Keras are also industry standards.
There’s less need to develop novel algorithms or techniques to approach problems that are already solved.
Some standard machine learning libraries already have good performing ML and deep learning architectures methods and classes available.
Trying to get a grasp on AI as an academic or a professional can be quite challenging.
Luckily for us, the general AI and Data Science community are somewhat helpful and willing to assist individuals who are starting, or can’t seem to fix that CUDA out of memory error!

If none of the questions included in this article applies to you, or you would like to ask me more questions related to machine learning, then feel free to ask questions in the comment section of this article.
I’ll respond to the best of my abilities. Or perhaps other readers might have answers to questions you might want to ask.
As I said, we have a responsive and helpful AI community.
